query: I work full-time but also care for my elderly father with Parkinson's in cambridgeshire. What respite care options exist so I can have occasional breaks?

retrieved_documents.content:

morning, bathing, preparing meals etc.  
 
 
If you think a home care agency might not be able to provide the personalised service you would like, you might wish to consider using a 
Direct Payment to employ a Personal Assistant to support you.  
 
You can find Personal Assistants through the council’s accredited 
Personal Assistant register. In Cambridgeshire, the register is run by 
People Plus Group https://peopleplus.co.uk/independent -living -
service/cambridgeshire  
 
You can also look at using a Care Mirco Enterprise (CME) provider, see 
our ‘Care Micro Enterprises’ info sheet for more information. Using the 
CME directory  you can find a provider who might suit your needs.  
 
Care in a residential or nursing home   
Residential care homes are for people who cannot continue to live at 
home, even with additional support or changes to their home. If people

. You can find information on the District Nurse on the NHS Cambridgeshire and Peterborough website . Types of care Those with the highest levels of need may need some personal care. Short term care Care Micro-Enterprises (CMEs) Care in your own home Residential care Video - jargon buster This video explains some of the terms and phrases you may hear around care and support. Visiting Support Service for Older People Providing extra support when you need it most, including support with bereavement, finances and paperwork. The Visiting Support Service for East Cambridgeshire, Fenland and Huntingdonshire residents is delivered by P3. There is also the Visiting Support Service for people in Cambridge City . And the Visiting Support Service for people in South Cambridgeshire

You can find out more at www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk
 by searching for 
‘Technology Enabled Care’.   
 
Reablement Service  
The council’s Reablement Team can support you to maximise your independence by helping you learn or regain the skills needed for everyday life.  
 
You can find out more at  www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk  search for ‘short 
term care’ . 
 
Care and support at home   
If you need support with personal care, such as washing yourself or 
getting dressed, you can employ a care worker to help you. A carer will 
visit you to help with activities of daily living such as getting up in the morning, bathing, preparing meals etc.   
As a self -funder you will be responsible for paying for your own care at 
home, but the council can help you find a care provider and, for a fee, 
will arrange and manage the contract with the provider for you.  
  If you choose to arrange your care yourself, you will need to consider what will happen when your money runs out. The council may not be

August 2024 
 Pictures  Words  
 There are also organisations that can help you if you 
have care and support needs. 
 You can find some information in this document.  
 
 
 Care Network  offer a free Help at Home Service for 
up to six weeks.  
 
In Cambridge, South Cambs and East Cambs you 
can call 01223 714433 or email hah.south@care-
network.org.uk  
 In Huntingdonshire and Fenland, you can call 01354 694413 or email hah.north@care -network.org.uk
 
 
 
 Care Network also have Community Navigators . 
Community Navigators  can help you to find the 
information you need about support and activities.  
 They can also suggest other organisations which can help you.  
You can find out more on www.care -network.org.uk

2 | Cambridgeshire County Council –  What happens if you need care and support when you leave 
hospital ? | August  2024  
 What  happens when I leave hospital ? 
You might need a bit of temporary support for a few days after leaving 
hospital whilst you recover and adapt  to new ways of doing things. You 
could ask your family or friends who live locally whether they might be able to help you. Often where informal support networks are able to help 
this can be preferable to people who do not know you.  
  
 
Also, there are a number of  voluntary sector and community groups who 
provide services specifically to help people with care and support needs.  
 
Care Network offers a free Help at Home service, for up to six weeks of 
practical and emotional support for any adult who has come out of 
hospital. You can find out more:   
 
• In Cambridge, South Cambs and East Cambs by calling 01223 
714433 or emailing hah.south@care -network.org.uk

[Page 2 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]
 
2 | Cambridgeshire County Council –  What happens if you need care and support when you leave 
hospital ? | August  2024  
 What  happens when I leave hospital ? 
You might need a bit of temporary support for a few days after leaving 
hospital whilst you recover and adapt  to new ways of doing things. You 
could ask your family or friends who live locally whether they might be able to help you. Often where informal support networks are able to help 
this can be preferable to people who do not know you.  
  
 
Also, there are a number of  voluntary sector and community groups who 
provide services specifically to help people with care and support needs.  
 
Care Network offers a free Help at Home service, for up to six weeks of 
practical and emotional support for any adult who has come out of 
hospital. You can find out more:   
 
• In Cambridge, South Cambs and East Cambs by calling 01223 
714433 or emailing hah.south@care -network.org.uk

[Page 10]
 
 
10 | Cambridgeshire County Council – If you need care and support when you leave hospital  - Easy Read | 
August 2024 
 Pictures  Words  
 You can find out more about Personal Assistants in 
Cambridgeshire by contacting People Plus  
Group at : https://peopleplus.co.uk/independent -
living -service/cambridgeshire  
 
Care in a residential or nursing home  
Pictures  Words  
 Care homes are for people who cannot stay at 
home. If you go into a care home straight from 
hospital, it might be difficult to go home later.  
 It is important to think about all other options first.  
 If this is your choice, then it is a good idea to look at 
the Care Quality Commission website.  
 They have reports about care homes. You can find the reports at www.cqc.org.uk
 
 You can ask someone to help you look at the reports to help you choose the best care home for your needs.

answer:
In Cambridgeshire, respite care options for carers like yourself include employing a Personal Assistant or using Care Micro Enterprises (CMEs) to provide support for your father, allowing you to take occasional breaks.

- **Personal Assistants**: You can employ a Personal Assistant using Direct Payments. These assistants can be found through the council’s accredited Personal Assistant register, managed by People Plus Group. More information is available at [People Plus Group](https://peopleplus.co.uk/independent-living-service/cambridgeshire).

- **Care Micro Enterprises (CMEs)**: These are small care providers that might offer the personalized service you need. You can find a suitable provider using the CME directory. For more information, refer to the 'Care Micro Enterprises' info sheet on the Cambridgeshire County Council website.

- **Care Network Services**: The Care Network offers a free Help at Home Service for up to six weeks, which might be useful if your father has recently been in the hospital. Contact them at 01223 714433 or via email at hah.south@care-network.org.uk for Cambridge, South Cambs, and East Cambs, or 01354 694413 for Huntingdonshire and Fenland.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Cambridgeshire County Council's website at [Cambridgeshire County Council](https://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk/residents/adults/organising-care-and-support/care-and-support-information-sheets).

test_metadata.prompt_template:
Please answer the following question about social care services in UK local authorities based only on the information in the provided documents.

Question: {query}

Context from relevant documents:
{context}

Instructions:
1. Provide a clear, direct answer that would help someone needing this information. If information isn't available, state: "The available documents don't provide specific information about [aspect]."

2. Synthesize information from ALL relevant documents to provide the most complete answer rather than analyzing documents individually.

3. Structure your response with:
   - A concise 1-2 sentence summary first
   - Relevant details organized in short, clear paragraphs
   - Bullet points for lists or step-by-step information
   - Bold text for key information the user should notice

4. For financial information:
   - Include exact figures, time periods, and what the funding covers
   - Present financial data clearly: "The adult social care budget is **£X million** for [time period]"

5. Always include practical next steps or resources:
   - Provide contact information, URLs, or application methods mentioned in the documents
   - Suggest where the person could find more information

6. When citing sources, use a simple format: "According to [document name/description]" or include URLs where available.

Answer:
